qas.question: On runways, what indicate the beginning of the runway for landing?
On runways, what indicate the end of the runway?
What indicates the edge of a runway?
What may low-traffic airports use to save electricity and staffing costs?
What does runway edge lighting indicate for landing?
What marks the end of the ALS at low-traffic airports?
What does using an ALS help save?

plausible_answers.text: white lights spaced out on both sides of the runway

qas.question: What does pilot controlled lighting consist of?
What do red lights down the the center of the runway indicate?

context: On runways, <a0_0>green lights<a0_0/> indicate <b5_0>the beginning of the runway<b5_0/> for landing, while <a1_0><b6_0>red lights<b6_0/><a1_0/> indicate <b9_0>the end of the runway<b9_0/>. Runway edge lighting consists of <a2_0><b8_0>white lights<a2_0/> spaced out on both sides of the runway<b8_0/>, indicating the edge. Some airports have more complicated lighting on the runways including lights that run down the centerline of the runway and lights that help indicate the approach (an <a4_0>approach lighting system<a4_0/>, or ALS). Low-traffic airports may use <a3_0>pilot controlled lighting<a3_0/> to save <b7_0>electricity and staffing costs<b7_0/>.
